questions.text: Which zone demonstrates the most optimal healing in the repair of a meniscal tear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Red zone

Explanation:

The red zone of the meniscus, which has a good blood supply, also exhibits the best healing potential.

 

Meniscal repair" data-author="" data-hash="12317" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ePN74UlRFNngCnji5Fok1746601931.png" />

 

Meniscal tears are common knee injuries that often require surgical repair.

  • The meniscus is a C-shaped cartilage structure located in the knee joint, providing stability, load distribution, and shock absorption.
  • The meniscus is divided into different zones based on its vascularity and healing potential.
  • The red-white zone, where the vascular and avascular portions of the meniscus meet, has a good healing potential.
  • The red zone is the outermost region of the meniscus and has a good blood supply, allowing for the best healing capacity.
  • The white zone is the innermost region of the meniscus and has a poor blood supply, limiting its healing potential.
  • Repairing a meniscal tear in the red-white zone has the highest likelihood of successful healing due to the presence of a good blood supply.
  • Surgical techniques used for meniscal repair include suturing, meniscal fixation devices, and meniscal transplantation.
  • Postoperative rehabilitation and physical therapy are crucial for optimal recovery and functional outcomes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following tests is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Thomas test

Explanation:

  • This test is used to assess the presence of hip flexion contracture and to measure hip extension.
  • If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended.

 

Thomas Test :

  • Thomas Test is a clinical examination used to assess hip flexion contracture (tightness of the hip flexors), particularly the iliopsoas muscle. It helps detect hip flexor tightness or shortening which may be contributing to lower back or hip pain. The test is especially useful in diagnosing conditions such as iliopsoas syndrome or hip joint stiffness.

Steps in Thomas Test:

  1. Position the Patient:
  2. Flex the Contralateral Hip:
  3. Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table).
  4. Evaluate Knee Flexion
    • Positive Thomas Test: The involved leg rises off the table or the knee remains flexed. This suggests hip flexor contracture (tightness of the iliopsoas or other hip flexors), which may limit the ability of the patient to fully extend the hip.
    • Negative Thomas Test: The involved leg remains flat on the table, with little to no knee flexion, indicating that there is no significant hip flexor tightness.

 

Telescopy (Option C) Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement.

Lasegue test (Option B) Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression.

McMurray test (Option D) Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear.

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman slipped and fell in the bathroom, experiencing pain and an inability to walk due to a left hip injury, without any prior osteoarthritis history, and with an observation of a shortened and externally rotated left lower limb according to X-ray findings, how would you plan to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Hemiarthroplasty

Explanation:

  • The X-ray image provided shows a left hip fracture. This patient is an elderly female who fell and is unable to walk, with shortened, externally rotated lower limb which is suggestive of displaced fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • A hemiarthroplasty is the most appropriate option for this patient. It involves replacing the femoral head and neck with a prosthetic implant. This procedure is generally preferred for older patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, which the X-ray image indicates.

 

 

Internal Fixation with Cancellous Screws (Option A) This option may be suitable for certain types of hip fractures, but it may not be appropriate for displaced femoral neck fractures, which are more common in the elderly.

Meyer's Operation (Option B) It involves cutting and repositioning the femur to correct the deformity. This option may not be suitable for elderly patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, as it is a more invasive procedure.

McMurray's Osteotomy (Option D) It involves cutting the femur to correct the deformity. This option may not be suitable for elderly patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, as it is a more invasive procedure.

questions.text: A young male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his lower limb was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Posterior dislocation of hip

Explanation:

The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip, which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened (FADIR). Sciatic nerve is commonly injured in posterior hip dislocation.

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • The femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
  • Nerve injury: common, sciatic nerve is injured.
  • Arterial injury: rare
  • Nerve injury: rare
  • Arterial injury: relatively more common, Femoral artery is injured

 

Absence of any fracture line on x-ray and no history of pain/swelling in the scenario rules out Intertrochanteric fracture of the femur (Option A) and Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels (Option B)

questions.text: A 74-year-old man, who was previously a weightlifter, presented with lower back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination , a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region of the spine. The x-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spondylolisthesis

Explanation:

Palpable step in the lumbosacral region with x-ray showing forward displacement of vertebra and intervertebral disc narrowing is suggestive of Spondylolisthesis.

Spondylolisthesis

               

  • It refers to the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one beneath it
  • Commonly occurring at the L5-S1 and L4-L5 levels.
  • Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars without the vertebra slipping forward.

Classification

Dysplastic

  • Least common type
  • Caused by congenital anomalies in the upper sacrum or L5 arch, facilitating the slip.

Isthmic

  • The most common type
  • Involving a lesion in the pars interarticularis, which can be further divided into three subtypes:
  • Lytic: A fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
  • Intact but elongated: The pars interarticularis remains intact but is elongated.
  • Acute fracture: A recent fracture of the pars interarticularis. The defect causes the anterior half of the vertebra to slip forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.

Degenerative

  • Results from long-term intersegmental instability, where the pars remains intact, but degenerative changes in the facet joints permit forward slipping.
  • Common in older adults, where instability in the posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis can lead to displacement, occasionally backwards (retrolisthesis).
  • Severe displacement and neurological issues are rare.

Traumatic

This results from fractures in other parts of the bony structure rather than in the pars interarticularis.

Pathological

Caused by generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the vertebral articulations.

 

X-ray Examination for Spondylolisthesis

Lateral View:

  • Shows anterior displacement of one vertebra over another.

Oblique View:

  • Reveals defects in the pars interarticularis.

 

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis (Option A)

Spondylolisthesis (Option B)
  • Resembles a Scottish dog
  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)
  • Defect without vertebral displacement
  • Separated Head and Neck
  • Defect with vertebral displacement

Incorrect Options:

Disc Prolapse (Option C): Is a herniated disc and the bulging of the disc can press the nerve roots and surrounding structures around the vertebrae. It can result in severe lower back pain.

Spondylosis (Option D): It is characterized by wear on the cervical vertebrae.It results in chronic neck pain. This is a chronic condition that affects the bone and cartilage of the cervical vertebrae.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness, and recurrent episodes of eye pain with redness. On examination, they are found to have anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) HLA B27

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of back pain, stiffness, anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)
 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)
 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 
  • Bamboo spine

 
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test
 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test


 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance
 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)
 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence for the Thomas test:

 

1. Squaring of pelvis

2. Flexion of the hip

3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis

4. Measure actual flexion deformity

5.Make sure that the ischial tuberosity makes contact with the ground.

6. Overcorrection of the normal side
questions.solution:
Steps in Thomas Test:

  1. Position the Patient, look for lumbar lordosis
  2. Flex the Contralateral Hip:
  3. Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table).
  4. Evaluate Knee Flexion

 

Interpretation:

  • If an opposite leg is flat: Good hip flexibility
  • If the opposite leg lifts off the table, but the hip is flexed: Hip flexor contracture If the opposite leg lifts off and the hip is extended: The hip flexor and extensor contracture
  • Hence the correct sequence of the Thomas test is:
  • Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis → Flexion of hip → Overcorrection of normal side → Ensure ischial tuberosity touches the ground → Measure actual flexion deformity.


Squaring of the pelvis (Statement 1) is not done in Thomas’ test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a cast, due to tibia fracture, presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense pain. The cast was removed and on physical examination, passive extension of leg was painful. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• The Clinical scenario of pain on passive extension after a trauma is likely to be compartment syndrome.
  • The next step is to measure the pressure in the anterior compartment if there is suspicion of compartment syndrome.
  • Normal pressure at the leg is < 11 mm of Hg.
  • Calf pressure during walking is 200-300 mm Hg.
  • Pressure in compartment syndrome >40 mmHg.

Acute compartment syndrome is caused by ischemia of a closed compartment of the body (most commonly forearm) which leads to increased intra-compartmental pressure.

  • It may be due to a decrease in compartment size or an increase in the volume of the compartment.
  • Prolonged ischemia will lead to myonecrosis stimulating fibrosis resulting in a fibrotic pull of the wrists and fingers.

 

Causes include:

  1. Tight bandages and dressings
  2. Animal bites
  3. Burns
  4. Intensive and excessive exercises
  5. Muscle hypertrophy
  6. Neoplasms
  7. Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder)
  8. Injections in the forearm
  9. Surgery on the forearm

 

Clinical Features:

Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome (Order of appearance)

  • Pain: The earliest symptom, worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain
  • Pallor: Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply.
  • Pulselessness: Diminished or absent radial pulse.
  • Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression.
  • Paralysis: Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia.

 

Management of ACS:

1. Monitor closely for symptoms of compartment syndrome (Severe pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, muscle weakness).

 

2. Measure Compartment Pressure

  • If pressure is below 20 mm Hg: Conservative management.
  • If pressure is between 20-30 mmHg: Monitor closely for worsening.
  • If pressure is above 30 mm Hg or Delta P is less than 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.

 

3. Conservative Management (If pressure < 20 mm Hg or borderline)

  • Elevate limb to heart level - helps reduce edema and venous congestion without compromising arterial inflow.
  • Remove tight dressings or splints.
  • Monitor pain, swelling, and sensation.
  • Repeat compartment pressure measurements regularly.
  • Optimize blood pressure and hydration.

 

4. Monitor for Progression

  • If symptoms worsen or pressure rises above 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy.
  • If symptoms improve: Continue conservative measures and monitoring.

 

5. Fasciotomy (If pressure > 30 mm Hg or worsening clinical signs): Volar Fasciotomy

 

6. Post-Fasciotomy Care - Wound care, physical therapy, and monitoring for complications (e.g., scarring or contractures).

 

Duplex imaging (Option A) may be used in suspected vascular injury or deep vein thrombosis cases.

Re-apply cast (Option B) further complicates the condition. Hence, the cause should be treated initially.

Analgesics (Option D) is used only temporarily for pain relief and cannot be considered the next step to manage this case.

questions.text:
After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide?
 

1. Thomas splint

2. K-wire

3. Steinmann pin

4. Denham's pin

5. Bohler's stirrup

6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 3, 5, 6

Explanation:

Steinmann pins can be used for skeletal traction by inserting into the tibia following a shaft of femur fracture where 10% of body weight or 20 kg of weight is used.

  • Bohler’s stirrup is a device that holds the Steinmann pin and is used to maintain traction.
  • Bohler Braun splint has 3 pulleys and is used to immobilise and support lower limb fractures by maintaining traction.

Instrument

Images

Proximal Femur Nail (PFN)

  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures.
  • It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw.
  • Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures.
  • It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures.

Kuntscher Nail

  • Used for internal fixation of femoral fractures.
  • The nail is a hollow tube with a cloverleaf shape for rotational stability.
  • Fixation is based on three-point fixation: at both ends and the isthmus.
  • Each end has an "eye" for the extractor hook during removal.
  • Nail size is determined by measuring from the greater trochanter to the lateral knee joint line and subtracting 2 cm.
  • About 2 cm of the nail is left protruding at the trochanter for removal, usually 2 years post-operation.

Kirschner wire (K wire)

  • Thin, straight steel wire with a diameter of 1 to 3 mm.
  • Uses include:
    • Internal fixation of small bones.
    • Tension band wiring in patella
    • Applying traction (e.g., through the olecranon).
    • Fixing fractures in children.
    • Used in Ilizarov’s fixation system.

Steinmann Pin

  • Stout, straight steel rod with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm.
  • Primarily used for skeletal traction.
  • Common sites for insertion include the upper end of the tibia, the supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum.

Bohler’s Stirrup

  • A device used for holding a Steinmann pin and applying traction.
  • Side screws secure the pin in place.
  • Allows for changing the direction of traction without moving the pin inside the bone.
  • Helps avoid loosening of the pin during traction adjustments.

Thomas Splint:

  • Primarily for the stabilization and immobilization of fractures in the femur or tibia.
  • It consists of a metal frame that supports the limb, preventing movement and reducing the risk of further injury.

Steinmann Pin:

  • It is a large, stainless steel pin used for internal fixation of fractures or to stabilize bones during surgery.
  • Typically inserted percutaneously (through the skin) or during surgery and is used to hold bones in place for proper healing.

Denham's Pin:

  • It is used for joint stabilization, often in the hip joint.
  • It is inserted into the bone and can be used for traction or temporary stabilization while healing.

Bohler-Braun Splint:

  • Splint used for the immobilization of fractures, especially in the thigh and leg.
  • It is a two-piece splint made of metal and is commonly used for fractures of the femur and tibia.

questions.text:
Following a road traffic accident, a patient develops type IIIa compound tibial fracture. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest)

1. Ilizarov fixator

2. Uniplanar with a single rod

3. Uniplanar with double rod

4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) 1 > 4 > 3 > 2

Explanation:

Highest to the lowest order of their stability starts with Ilizarov > Biplanar frame > Uniplanar with double rod > Uniplanar with a single rod.

  • Ilizarov fixator: The Ilizarov fixator is the most stable fixator. It uses a ring-based system with multiple rods and wires that provide a high degree of stability and control over the alignment and position of the bone fragments. The fixator can be adjusted in multiple planes, providing more stability and making it effective for complex fractures like type IIIa compound tibial fractures.
  • Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod: This fixator provides stability through its ring configuration, with the added benefit of a cylindrical rod that increases strength. The biplanar design gives good stabilization in two planes, making it more stable than uniplanar designs but less so than the Ilizarov.
  • Uniplanar with double rod: A uniplanar fixator with double rods provides more stability than a single rod because of the additional support, but it only stabilizes in one plane. It's less stable than biplanar or Ilizarov systems due to the reduced number of support structures and limited planes of control.
  • Uniplanar with a single rod: This is the least stable option because it provides minimal support and only in one plane. It’s commonly used for less complex fractures but doesn’t offer the same level of stability needed for more severe fractures like a type IIIa compound tibial fracture.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What will be the next step of management?

choices.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
Open reduction and reconstruction of posterior pillar of acetabulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

Explanation:

  • The above X-ray shows characteristics of posterior dislocation of the left hip. Deformity observed is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip. Closed reduction is a non-surgical technique to realign the displaced bone to its normal position.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 
 

Management of posterior hip dislocation:

Immediate Reduction:

  • Reduction must be performed as soon as possible as delays over 6 hours increase risks of osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis.
  • Closed reduction is preferred unless a femoral neck fracture is present.

 

CT pelvis with 3D reconstruction (Option B) can give a better view of the structures around the hip joint and help detect associated fractures. Not used for first line management

High-weight skeletal traction (Option C) The immediate next step of managing posterior hip dislocation would be closed reduction initially, followed by traction for 3 weeks.

Open reduction and reconstruction of the posterior pillar of the acetabulum (Option D) Open reduction is an invasive procedure, and hence it is required only if closed reduction is unsuccessful or if there is a loose intra-articular fragment which prevents proper reduction, or if the acetabular fragment is large.
