questions.text: What is the term used to describe the fracture shown in the image, which occurred due to a fall from a significant height?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Open book fracture

Explanation:

Both arches being separated at anterior and posterior ends caused by an anteroposterior compression injury to the pelvis is suggestive of Open Book fracture Pelvis. Open book - Pelvic ring fracture is classified under Class B1 of Tile’s classification of Pelvic ring injuries.

Tile’s classification of Pelvic ring injuries:

Type A: Stable (Intact posterior arch)

A1

Avulsion injury

A2

Iliac-wing or anterior arch fracture

A3

Transverse sacrococcygeal fracture

Type B: Partially stable (incomplete disruption of the posterior arch)

B1

Open-book injury (external rotation) (Option A)

B2

Lateral-compression injury (internal rotation)

B2-1: Ipsilateral anterior and posterior injuries

B2-2: Contralateral (bucket-handle) injuries (Option D)

 

B3

Bilateral

Type C: Unstable (complete disruption of the posterior arch)

C1

Unilateral

C2

Bilateral, with one side type B, one side type C

C3

Bilateral

Incorrect Options:

Chauffeur Fracture (Option B): Type of intra-articular fracture of the radial styloid with radiostyloid joint subluxation. It is also known as Hutchinson or Backfire fracture.

Malgaigne Fracture (Option C): It is an unstable pelvic fracture characterized by anterior portion of pelvis namely pubic rami and posterior portion of the pelvis involving sacroiliac complex.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 22-year-old male patient presenting with a history of accident, exhibiting leg abduction and external rotation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anterior dislocation of the hip

Explanation:

Anterior hip dislocation

Classification
  • Type I: Pubic (superior) injuries
  • Type II: Obturator (inferior) injuries

Management
  • Reduction should be performed as soon as possible under sedation or general anesthesia.
  • Closed reduction technique:
    • Hold the affected leg in external rotation, abduction, and flexion.
    • Apply longitudinal traction.
    • Internally and externally rotate the leg until reduction is achieved, and apply anterior pressure on the femoral head if necessary.
    • If repeated attempts fail, consider an open reduction.

Complications
  • Injury to the sciatic nerve.
  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head: may require hip replacement if osteoarthritis develops.

 

 

  •   Osteoarthritis: develops years later. Treatment varies from conservative to total hip replacement.

 

  • Myositis Ossificans: Develops weeks to months post-injury and is characterized by pain and stiffness. Ill-advised vigorous and improper massage following trauma is the most common cause.Treatment includes rest and analgesics.

 

  • Potential for associated femoral head fractures.

 

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B ruled out)

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

 

 

 

 

An Intertrochanteric fracture (Option C) is a fracture of the femur that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanter. It typically presents with pain and inability to bear weight, but not necessarily with leg abduction and external rotation. This injury is usually associated with falls or trauma but doesn't typically cause the specific positioning of the leg seen in dislocations.

A fracture of the femoral neck (Option D) typically presents with shortening, external rotation, and abduction of the leg, but this injury is more commonly seen in elderly patients with osteoporosis, particularly following falls. While there can be external rotation, abduction is more characteristic of a posterior dislocation or intertrochanteric fracture rather than a femoral neck fracture.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit 48 hours after fracturing their femur, with a saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit at 100%, but their SpO2 remained at 60%? The patient is also experiencing confusion, and a chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism due to the combination of confusion, petechial rash, tachycardia, tachypnea, and low oxygen saturation following a femur fracture.

Fat Embolism
  • Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures.

Classic Triad
  • Hypoxia
  • Petechiae
  • Altered mental status

Other Symptoms

  • Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis).

Etiology
  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Pathogenesis

  • Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Investigation
  • Chest X-ray: Commonly clear lung fields, occasionally Snowstorm appearance is seen (pathognomonic)
  • PaO₂ <60 mm Hg
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO₂
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

Incorrect Options:

Pulmonary Embolism (Option B): typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and tachycardia, but lacks the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in this case. Additionally, the patient's history of femur fracture points more strongly to fat embolism rather than pulmonary embolism.

ARDS (Option C): typically presents with sudden onset breathlessness associated with hypoxemia and diffuse alveolar infiltrates on x-ray.

Occult Pneumothorax (Option D): presents with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds, which differs from the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in fat embolism, especially after femur fractures.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling around his right knee. There is no history of trauma. On examination, there is localised tenderness over the distal femur. X-ray reveals sclerotic changes in the metaphyseal region, with features such as sequestrum and involucrum. Laboratory investigations show mild leukocytosis and elevated ESR. Which of the following is the least expected causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Explanation:

  • The presentation and imaging findings suggest chronic bacterial osteomyelitis of the metaphyseal region of the distal femur, which is common in children due to hematogenous spread of infection.
  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is rarely a cause of chronic osteomyelitis in healthy pediatric patients.
  • It more commonly causes infections in hospitalized, immunocompromised, or adult patients with underlying conditions.
  • Chronic Osteomyelitis:
    • According to Waldvogel's classification, it is an osteomyelitis persisting for more than 4 weeks.
    • Most common cause - Staphylococcus aureus (Same in both acute and subacute osteomyelitis)
    • In foreign body implants - Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common
  • Streptococcus pyogenes can cause both acute and chronic osteomyelitis. (Option A)
  • Escherichia coli & Mycobacterium tuberculosis also cause chronic osteomyelitis but not as commonly as Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. (Option B & C)

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with a progressively increasing swelling over the tibia along with fever. Radiological examination reveals a Codman triangle and sunburst appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Based on the presentation and the radiological findings of codman triangle and sunburst appearance, the most likely diagnosis is Osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma:

  • It is the most common primary malignant tumour of bone and accounts for approximately 20% of bone cancers.
  • Age distribution: Bimodal.
  • Tumours usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones; almost 50% are near the knee in the distal femur or proximal tibia.
  • Genetic associations:
    • RB gene (most common): 70%.
    • TP53.
    • CDKN2A (also known as INK4a).
    • MDM2 and CDK4.
  • Morphology:
    • Osteosarcomas are bulky, gritty, grey-white tumours that often contain haemorrhage and cystic degeneration.
    • Osteosarcomas demonstrate pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, bizarre tumour giant cells, and abundant mitoses.
    • Extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are also common.
    • Diagnosis of osteosarcoma requires the presence of malignant tumour cells producing unmineralised osteoid or mineralised bone.
  • Osteosarcoma metastasises hematogenously to the lungs, bones, brain, and other sites.
  • X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:
    • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
    • Sun-ray or Sun burst appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle

Ewing sarcoma (Option B) is the second most common in children and young adults and its radiology shows onion-skin appearance, not Codman triangle or sunburst pattern.

Giant cell tumour (Option C) is a benign but locally aggressive tumour characterised by numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells. It occurs in the third to fifth decades of life. Radiology shows soap bubble appearance, which is lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition

﻿﻿﻿Chondrosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant cartilage-producing tumour. It is the second most common malignant matrix-producing tumour of the bone and affects individuals usually in their 40s or older. They commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. It does not show Codman triangle or sunburst pattern in a X-ray.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female sustained an Intertrochanteric Fracture. Which of the following is the Best Management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proximal Femoral Nail

Explanation:

  • Proximal Femoral Nail (intramedullary fixation) is the treatment of choice for most intertrochanteric fractures, especially unstable patterns, which are common in the elderly.
  • Its is a fracture between the greater and lesser trochanters may lead to slight disruption of Shenton's line due to misalignment, often less pronounced than neck fractures. It is almost always managed by internal fixation with implants (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)
  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures.
  • It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw.
  • Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures. It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures.

 

 

Aspect

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

Walking is not possible due to the instability

Blood Loss

More blood loss, due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Complications

Malunion is more common than nonunion


Internal Fixation with Screws (Option B) is better suitable for femoral neck fractures, not intertrochanteric fractures as it does not provide sufficient stability in osteoporotic bone.

Prosthetic Replacement (Option C) is done in femoral neck fractures, especially when there's risk of avascular necrosis or poor healing. It is not typically used for intertrochanteric fractures unless there's severe comminution or failed fixation, and in elderly with osteoporosis.

Boot & Traction (Option D) was previously used for temporary alignment and pain relief. It does not provide fracture stability or promote healing, it's not definitive treatment.

questions.text: A young adult patient presents with a fracture of the neck of the femur. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Internal fixation

Explanation:

The most appropriate management for a femoral neck fracture in a young adult is internal fixation. This method involves surgically inserting screws or a plate to stabilize the fracture while preserving the patient's natural hip joint.

  • Preserving the Femoral Head: Unlike older patients, young adults have a higher potential for the femoral head to heal and maintain its blood supply. Internal fixation is chosen to preserve the native femoral head and joint, which is crucial for a young, active patient.
  • Preventing Complications: The goal is to achieve an accurate reduction and stable fixation to promote healing and reduce the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis (AVN) and nonunion, which are more likely if the fracture is not treated correctly.

Incorrect Options:

External fixation (Option A) is typically used for temporary stabilization in cases of polytrauma or open fractures but is not the definitive treatment for a femoral neck fracture.

Hemiarthroplasty (Option C) involves replacing the femoral head but not the acetabulum. It is primarily reserved for elderly, low-demand patients who are not expected to have a good outcome with internal fixation.

Total hip replacement (Option D) involves replacing both the femoral head and the acetabulum. This is the gold standard for treating arthritic hips or for elderly, active patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, but it is generally avoided in young adults to preserve the native joint for as long as possible.

questions.text: A patient was in a road traffic accident and presented with the following fracture. What type of fracture is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intertrochanteric fracture

Explanation:

The image shows a fracture that occurs in the proximal femur, specifically in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. This is the definition of an intertrochanteric fracture.

  • Location: This type of fracture is located in the extracapsular region of the hip joint, meaning it is outside the joint capsule. This is an important distinction because the blood supply to the femoral head is typically well-preserved in these fractures, leading to a lower risk of avascular necrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Characteristics: These fractures are often comminuted (broken into multiple fragments) and can have a spiral or oblique pattern. They are common in elderly patients, often resulting from a simple fall.

Incorrect Options:

Subtrochanteric fracture (Option A) occurs below the lesser trochanter, in the shaft of the femur.

Femoral neck fracture (Option C) occurs within the joint capsule (intracapsular) and is located superior to the intertrochanteric region. It is associated with a higher risk of avascular necrosis.

Pubic rami fracture (Option D) is a type of pelvic fracture and is not a fracture of the femur.

questions.text: Injury to which part causes difficulty in dorsiflexion of the foot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – B:

Explanation:

The x-ray shows nerves labelled around the knee. B is pointing to the common peroneal nerve.

  • Function of the Common Peroneal Nerve: The common peroneal nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the lower leg. Specifically, it branches into the deep and superficial peroneal nerves. The deep peroneal nerve innervates the tibialis anterior muscle, which is the primary muscle responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot (lifting the foot upward).
  • Clinical Significance: Injury to the common peroneal nerve, which is common due to its superficial location around the fibular head, results in the inability to dorsiflex the foot. This condition is known as foot drop, where the foot hangs down and the patient has to lift their leg high to avoid dragging their toes while walking.

Incorrect Options:

A- Sciatic nerve (Option A) is the main nerve of the leg. An injury to this nerve would cause much more widespread weakness, affecting both dorsiflexion and plantarflexion, as well as the hamstring muscles.

C- Tibial nerve (Option C) innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the lower leg, which are responsible for plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward). An injury to this nerve would cause difficulty in plantarflexion.

D- Deep peroneal nerve (Option D) is a terminal branch of the common peroneal nerve. While an injury to this specific branch would cause foot drop, the injury at the level of the common peroneal nerve (B) is a more common site of injury.

questions.text: Which ligament is tested in the following test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior cruciate ligament

Explanation:

The image depicts the anterior drawer test, a clinical maneuver used to assess the integrity of the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL). The test is performed by:

  • Flexing the patient's knee to 90 degrees.
  • Stabilizing the patient's femur with one hand.
  • Pulling the tibia forward with the other hand.

Incorrect Options:

Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) (Option B) is tested using the posterior drawer test, where the examiner pushes the tibia backward.

Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) (Option C) is assessed with the valgus stress test, which involves applying a force to the outside of the knee to test for gapping on the medial side.

Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) (Option D) is assessed with the varus stress test, which involves applying a force to the inside of the knee to test for gapping on the lateral side.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motorbike accident and is found to have a closed midshaft fracture of the left tibia. Six hours later, he develops severe leg pain that is disproportionate to the injury and worsens with passive dorsiflexion of the foot. The pain is not relieved by analgesics. On examination, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present, but there is no sensation over the first dorsal webspace. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer opioid analgesics and continue observation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Immediate fasciotomy

Explanation:

  • Acute compartment syndrome (ACS) is a surgical emergency caused by raised intracompartmental pressure impairing perfusion.
  • Hallmark signs:
    • Severe, out-of-proportion pain.
    • Pain on passive stretch (earliest finding).
    • Sensory deficits (late sign) — here, loss over first dorsal webspace suggests deep peroneal nerve involvement.
    • Pulses usually present until late stages.
  • Management algorithm:
    • Positive clinical diagnosis → immediate fasciotomy without waiting for confirmatory tests.
    • In doubtful cases, measure intracompartmental pressure (ICP).
      • ICP > 30 mmHg → fasciotomy.
      • ICP < 30 mmHg → conservative measures.
  • Delay in fasciotomy risks irreversible muscle and nerve necrosis.

Elevate the limb and observe (Option A): Limb elevation above heart level can further reduce perfusion pressure and worsen ischemia in ACS; observation alone delays definitive management.

Administer opioid analgesics and continue observation (Option C): Analgesics do not treat the underlying ischemia; delaying fasciotomy can cause permanent damage within hours.

Apply cast and follow up (Option D): Applying a cast in suspected ACS is dangerous, as it can further increase compartment pressure and worsen ischemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with painless limping. Based on the X-ray shown, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perthe’s disease

Explanation:

  • Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, typically affects children aged 4 to 10 years and is characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head, presenting with painless limping or mild hip pain, and X-rays showing flattening, fragmentation, and sclerosis of the femoral head.

Idiopathic osteonecrosis or idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis of the femoral head.

Etiopathogenesis

Includes 4 phases

  • Necrosis: Disruption of the blood supply leads to infarction of the femoral capital epiphysis.
  • Fragmentation: The body reabsorbs the infarcted bone.
  • Reossification: Osteoblastic activity takes over, and the femoral epiphysis reestablishes.
  • Remodeling: The new femoral head may be enlarged or flattened. It reshapes during growth.

Clinical features
  • Limp of acute or insidious onset, usually painless.
  • If pain is present, it is localized to the hip or knee.
  • Decreased internal rotation and abduction of hip.
  • Atrophy of thighs and buttocks.
  • Leg length discrepancy.
  • Antalgic gait in acute cases
  • Trendelenburg gait in chronic cases

Diagnosis
  • Standard anteroposterior pelvis and frog-leg lateral (Lauenstein) views.
  • Bone scan or MRI

 

Early findings:

  • Widening of joint space (epiphyseal cartilage hypertrophy)
  • Changes in the epiphysis.
  • Crescent sign: Subchondral radiolucent zone of the anterolateral epiphysis

Late signs:

  • Flattening of the femoral head.
  • Bone scan shows decreased perfusion to the femoral head.

Treatment

Non operative:

  • Indicated for children with bone age less than 6 or lateral pillar A involvement.
  • Activity restriction and protective weight-bearing are recommended until ossification is complete.

 

Operative treatment:

  • Femoral or Pelvic Osteotomy indicated in children older than 8 years.
  • Valgus or Shelf Osteotomies indicated in children with hinge abduction
  • Hip Arthroscopy

Complications
  • Coxa magna: Widening of the femoral head.
  • Coda plans: Flattening of the femoral head.

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) (Option B) typically affects adolescents (older than 10 years), presents with painful limp, and X-ray shows displacement of the femoral head relative to the neck.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) (Option C) is usually diagnosed earlier in infancy or early childhood, with hip instability or dislocation.

Osteomalacia (Option D) affects bone mineralization and is rare in children; it usually presents with bone pain and deformities rather than isolated limping.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibrous dysplasia

Explanation:

Lower limb deformity with x-ray showing ground glass lesion, ‘shepherd crook deformity’ with associated skin lesions is suggestive of Fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia:

Description
  • Non-inherited developmental disorder causing replacement of bone by fibrous tissue

Etiology
  • GNAS1 gene mutation (Chromosome 20)
  • Associated with McCune Albright syndrome - Polyostotic Fibrous Dysplasia

Clinical presentation
  • Usually presents in the 2nd decade
  • Progressive limb pain, swelling
  • Limb deformities with associated fractures
  • Skin lesions (seen with McCune Albright syndrome)

Radiography
  • X-ray: well defined expansile intramedullary lesions with ‘Ground glass’ appearance, ‘shepherd crook deformity’.
  • MRI: is done to know the full extent of the disease

Management
  • Medical: Bisphosphonates
  • Surgical: Deformity correction surgeries

questions.text: A 45-year old female met with an accident and was brought to trauma centre and X-ray pelvis was performed and image is given below shows Intracapsular fracture NOF. What is the management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Open reduction+ Internal fixation

Explanation:

The best course of management in an Intracapsular neck of femur fracture in a 45 year old female is open reduction and internal fixation, due to higher risk of avascular necrosis.

Neck of femur fractures and intertrochanteric fractures

 

Aspect

Neck of Femur Fracture

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Intracapsular (within the joint capsule)

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 50 years

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Female > Male

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls)

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic)

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Less stable, especially if displaced

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

May be possible in impacted fractures

Walking is not possible due to the instability

External Rotation Deformity

Less than 45º

More than 45º

Shortening

Less than 1 inch

More than 1 inch

Blood Supply Involvement

High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption)

Lower risk of avascular necrosis

Blood Loss

Less blood loss due to intracapsular location

More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle.

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (Option D) (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty (Option B ruled out), total hip replacement)

Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

Malunion is more common than nonunion
 

Closed reduction (Option A) is not done because there is a high risk of avascular necrosis and non union of fracture

Open + Closed reduction (Option C) cannot be done at the same time and is not the best course of action.

questions.text: A 30-year-old met with a bike accident and presented with the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a lengthened limb with external rotation and abduction, which is characteristic of anterior hip dislocation.

 

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.


 

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central fracture-dislocation of hip

 

Mechanism of injury:
 

Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

 

 

  

 

 

 


 

Posterior Hip Dislocation (Option B): Would present with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation (not seen here).

Superior Hip Dislocation (Option C): Very rare, associated with high-energy trauma and pelvic fractures.

Both A and B (Option D): The presentation is specific to anterior dislocation only.

questions.text: Identify the orthopedic implant shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Dynamic Hip Screw

Explanation:

This is a commonly used orthopedic implant designed for the fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. It consists of a large screw that is inserted into the femoral head and a side plate that is fixed to the femoral shaft. The "dynamic" feature allows for controlled collapse of the fracture, promoting healing.

 

Adynamic Hip Screw (Option B) This term is incorrect or non-existent in orthopedic practice.

Condylar Hip Screw (Option C) This implant is used for fixing fractures around the distal femur, specifically the condylar region. It is not used for intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

Intramedullary Nail (Option D) is a long metal rod inserted into the medullary cavity of long bones, commonly used for diaphyseal fractures. It is not typically used for intertrochanteric femur fractures, although some variations (like a cephalomedullary nail) may be used in cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear cast?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 6-8 weeks:

  • This is the typical duration for casting a 5th metatarsal fracture. It allows adequate time for bone healing, considering the location and nature of the fracture. This duration helps ensure proper alignment and support, leading to better outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options

Options A,B and D are incorrect as given above

questions.text: A heavy lifter presents with lower back ache. Identify the nerve compressed in the following disc prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - L5:

  • This is the most common nerve root affected in disc prolapse, particularly in individuals who lift heavy weights. The L5 nerve root can be compressed by a prolapsed disc, leading to lower back pain, pain radiating down the posterior thigh, lateral aspect of the leg, and weakness in dorsiflexion of the foot (difficulty lifting the foot).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L4:

  • A disc prolapse affecting the L4 nerve root is less common. Compression at this level can cause symptoms such as pain and weakness in the anterior thigh and knee area, but typically, lower back pain from heavy lifting is more often associated with the L5 or S1 nerve roots.

Option C - S1:

  • Although the S1 nerve root can also be affected by disc prolapse, it typically results in pain and weakness in the posterior leg and plantar aspect of the foot. The S1 nerve root compression is less common in heavy lifters compared to L5.

Option D - S4:

  • Compression of the S4 nerve root is rare in cases of disc prolapse and is usually associated with issues in the sacral region. Symptoms related to S4 would include pelvic and perineal discomfort, which are not typically caused by heavy lifting.

questions.text: A man presents with back pain following road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spinous Process Fracture:

  • A spinous process fracture occurs when the bony projection off the back of a vertebra is broken. Hyperextension injuries typically cause this type of fracture and often presents with localized back pain without neurological deficits. X-rays show a fracture of the spinous process, but the vertebral body remains intact as given in the image.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Chance Fracture:

  • A Chance fracture, also known as a seatbelt fracture, is a type of spinal injury caused by hyperflexion of the spine, often associated with a lap belt during a car accident. It is characterized by a fracture through the vertebral body and posterior elements. On X-ray, it shows a horizontal fracture line through the vertebral body, which might be difficult to identify if only the spinous process is imaged.

 

Option C - Fracture of the Base of Vertebrae:

  • This type of fracture involves a break at the base of the vertebra, which could affect the anterior or posterior aspects of the vertebra. It may not always present with neurological symptoms immediately but could lead to instability. It might not always be obvious on X-rays unless specific views are used.

Option D - Compressed Fracture:

  • A compression fracture involves the collapse of the vertebral body, often due to axial load or trauma. It presents with back pain and is typically visible on X-rays as a decrease in vertebral body height. In the absence of neurological deficits, this is a common type of fracture resulting from trauma.

questions.text: Which area is affected by the fracture shown in the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Tibial tuberosity fracture

  • The lateral X-ray of the knee joint clearly shows a fracture involving the tibial tuberosity, which is the bony prominence on the anterior surface of the tibia just below the patella.

  • This is the insertion site for the patellar tendon, and fractures here are usually seen in adolescents during forceful quadriceps contraction (e.g., jumping sports).

Features of Tibial Tuberosity Fracture:

Feature Description
Location Anterior proximal tibia (tibial tuberosity)
Mechanism Forceful contraction of quadriceps (e.g., jumping, kicking)
Radiograph finding Fracture through or below the tibial tuberosity
Associated conditions May be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease as a predisposing factor

Medial epicondyle of tibia (Option B):
Incorrect — the fracture is not located medially; it's clearly anterior and involves the tibial tuberosity.

Gerdy's tubercle fracture (Option C):
Incorrect — Gerdy's tubercle is lateral, where the iliotibial band inserts. The fracture here is not lateral.

Osgood-Schlatter disease (Option D):
Incorrect — this is a chronic traction apophysitis, not an acute fracture. It causes pain and swelling, not a well-defined fracture line.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis occurs when one vertebra slips forward over the one below it, usually due to degeneration, trauma, or congenital defects. The CT scan in this case would show the misalignment of the vertebrae, explaining the patient's chronic back pain. This diagnosis is consistent with the clinical presentation and imaging findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paget's Disease:

  • Paget’s disease is a chronic bone disorder that can cause enlarged and deformed bones. On imaging, it typically shows thickened cortical bone, enlarged bones with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes, and a characteristic “cotton wool” appearance. This disease usually affects the pelvis, skull, spine, and long bones, but the imaging features would differ from those seen in spondylolisthesis.

Option B - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis leads to decreased bone density and increased fracture risk, especially in the spine, hips, and wrists. CT scans of patients with osteoporosis typically show generalized bone thinning, with possible compression fractures in the vertebrae, but not the characteristic vertebral slippage seen in spondylolisthesis.

Option D - Renal Osteodystrophy:

  • This is a bone pathology associated with chronic kidney disease, characterized by alterations in bone morphology. Imaging might show subperiosteal resorption, "rugger-jersey" spine, or osteosclerosis, but it would not show the vertebral slippage characteristic of spondylolisthesis.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anterior talofibular ligament

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in an inversion injury, as it is the weakest of the lateral ligaments and is directly stressed by inversion movements. The peroneus longus tendon, which helps evert the foot, can also be affected due to the force of the inversion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tibialis anterior tendon:

  • This tendon primarily functions to dorsiflex and invert the foot. While it plays a role in ankle stability, it is not typically injured in an inversion injury, which stresses the lateral ligaments rather than the anterior structures.

Option B - Tibialis posterior tendon:

  • This tendon is responsible for foot inversion and support of the medial arch. Injuries to the tibialis posterior tendon are more associated with overuse or medial stress rather than acute inversion injuries, which typically affect the lateral side of the ankle.

Option C - Extensor hallucis longus tendon:

  • This tendon controls the extension of the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is less commonly injured in inversion sprains, as it is not located in the lateral or medial regions of the ankle that bear the brunt of an inversion force.

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture in a patient who sustained a road traffic accident resulting in fractures of both the tibia and fibula.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Bumper fracture

Explanation:

  • A bumper fracture refers specifically to a lateral tibial plateau fracture, which commonly occurs in road traffic accidents. This type of fracture often involves both the tibia and fibula.

 

Classification of Tibial Plateau Fracture

The tibial plateau refers to the proximal tibial surface, which comprises the medial and lateral articular surfaces of the respective tibial condyles.

Lateral tibial plateau fractures are the most common.

Mechanism of Injury
  • The main mechanism of injury is a varus or valgus force, with or without axial load.
  • Young Adults: Road traffic accidents, leading to split fractures (high ligament injury risk).

  • Elderly: Trivial falls, causing depression or split depression fractures (associated with osteoporosis) (low ligament injury risk).

Classification (Schatzker)

Type I: Lateral plateau split fracture (young adults).

Type II: Lateral plateau split depression (young adults).

Type III: Lateral plateau pure depression (elderly).

Type IV: Medial plateau fracture.

Type V: Bicondylar fracture.

Type VI: Dissociation of metaphysis and diaphysis.

Clinical Features
  • Knee swelling due to hemarthrosis.
  • Inability to bear weight
  • Reduce range of knee movements
  • Compartment syndrome (earliest sign: stretch pain).

Imaging
  • X-ray: Initial fracture detection.

 

   

 

  • CT with 3D Reconstruction: Gold standard.
  • MRI: To assess ligament injuries.

Management
  • Non-surgical: Stable fractures with minimal displacement.
  • Surgical (ORIF): For displaced fractures or significant depression.
  • Ligament reconstruction if needed.

 

Patella sleeve fracture (Options B) This injury generally occurs from direct trauma to the front of the knee or from a fall, and while possible in road traffic accidents, it is less likely in this case where the deformity and mechanism suggest lateral tibial plateau involvement.

Depressed skull fracture (Options C) Typically caused by small objects impacting the skull at high velocity.

Cervical fracture (Options D) do not involve fracture of both tibia and fibula.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a fracture of the intracapsular neck of the femur. What is the standard management done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correcr Answer: A) Hemiarthroplasty

  • In elderly patients (>60 years) with intracapsular fracture neck of femur, blood supply to the femoral head is often compromised.

  • This leads to a high risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion, making internal fixation less favorable.

  • Hemiarthroplasty (replacement of the femoral head) is the standard treatment to allow early mobilization and reduce complications like bedsores, pneumonia, and DVT.

Fracture Neck of Femur 

Aspect Details
Common in Elderly, especially osteoporotic bones
Type of fracture Intracapsular (femoral neck, within joint capsule)
Risk Disruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis
Goal of treatment Restore mobility, minimize complications of immobility
Preferred treatment (elderly) Hemiarthroplasty – replacement of femoral head
Preferred treatment (young) Internal fixation with cannulated screws or DHS

 

Boot and bar cast (Option B): Incorrect because casting is not effective for femoral neck fractures in adults and leads to prolonged immobilization and complications.

Intramedullary nails (Option C): Incorrect because these are used for shaft or intertrochanteric fractures, not for intracapsular neck fractures.

Russell’s traction (Option D): Incorrect as it is outdated and not standard in current practice; it delays mobilization and increases complication risk.

questions.text: Which of he following layer is affected in a Salter-Harris type 1 fracture ?

choices.text: Calcific zone of the growth plate
Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate
The resting zone of the growth plate
Through the whole of the epiphysis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypertrophic or calcific layer:

  • Salter-Harris type 1 fracture is a complete separation of metaphysis and epiphysis without fracture.
  • Apart from trauma, it is common in rickets, scurvy, osteomyelitis.
  • The hypertrophic layer is involved.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D are incorrect as the hypertrophic layer ( weakest layer)is affected in Salter-Harris type 1 fracture

questions.text: In a 70-year-old female who presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture, what is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intramedullary nails: Extracapsular neck fractures are intertrochanteric fractures in which the vascularity is intact therefore intramedullary nailing is done to prevent malunion/coxa vara. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hemi arthroplasty: This is done in case of disrupted vascularity resulting in avascular necrosis or non-union

Option B - Boot and bar cast: This is done as a conservative management for the inoperable patients.

Option D - Russell's traction: This is mainly used for temporary stabilization and pain relief before definitive surgery, not as a definitive treatment.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis based on the x-ray image of a 22-year-old female?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant cell tumor

Explanation:

Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epi-metaphyseal region is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT).

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

Incorrect options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A):

  • Seen in 1st decade (before skeletal maturity)
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric epiphyseal lesion
  • Biopsy: Chicken wire calcification is pathognomic

 

Osteochondroma (Option B):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

 

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option D):

  • Variant of Giant cell tumor, seen in paediatric age group
  • X-ray: Soap bubble appearance
  • Biopsy: Blood filled cystic spaces seen.

questions.text: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?

choices.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bipartite fracture patella, X-ray of the opposite knee

Explanation:

In the absence of trauma with the given x-ray appearance showing 2 divided patellar segments is suggestive of Bipartite patella and the most appropriate next step in management is to take X-ray of opposite knee.

Bipartite Patella:

 

Definition

A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments.

Etiology
  • Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments.
  • Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral.

Anatomy

Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella.

Types

Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre,

  • Type I: Inferior pole of patella.
  • Type II: Lateral margin.
  • Type III: Superolateral (most common).

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment.

MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.

Differential Diagnosis

Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures).

Management
  • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
  • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.text: For which type of fractures does the Hawkins classification apply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Talus

Explanation:

Hawkin’s classification is used for fractures of the neck of the talus.

Hawkin’s classification:

Type I

Undisplaced fracture of the talar neck.

Type II

Displaced fracture with subluxation or dislocation of the subtalar joint.

Type III

Displaced fracture with dislocation of the talus body from the ankle joint.

Type IV

Displaced vertical talar neck fracture with associated disruption of the talonavicular joint.

 

Tibia (Option B): The Schatzker classification is used for categorizing tibial fracture

Humerus (Option C): The Neer's Classification is used for categorizing humerus head fracture.

Calcaneus (Option D): The Sanders classification is primarily used for categorizing fractures of the calcaneus.

questions.text: In the case of an ongoing bleeding in a patient with a fracture of the pelvic bone, what is the immediate action that needs to be taken to address the situation, if the patient is in hypotension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crystalloids

Explanation:

In a case of pelvic bone fracture with hypotension, the immediate next step will be to administer crystalloids and stabilise the patient.

Management steps to be followed in this patient:

  • Assessment of vital signs and initiation of ATLS protocol - administration of crystalloids.
  • Pelvic binder is applied to reduce bleeding and maintain hemostasis. (Option D)
  • An external fixator is then applied until the patient's hemodynamic status is stable, followed by internal definite fixation once the patient is fit for surgery.

Complications and Management of Pelvic fracture:

Shock:

  • Hemorrhagic shock from pelvic injury is the most common cause of mortality (30%).
  • Management:
  • Initial Management: Primary survey (ABCDE) and simultaneous resuscitation as per Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines. (Option A)
  • Laparotomy: Immediate laparotomy if the patient remains unstable.
  • Preperitoneal Packing (PPP): Used to create a tamponade effect.
  • Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta (REBOA): Uses balloon catheter to occlude the aorta in life-threatening hemorrhage ; Can be inflated for up to 60 minutes ; Intermittent inflation helps with resuscitation and reduces reperfusion injury.
  • Surgical Fixation for Unstable Pelvic Fractures:
  • External Fixation: Provides initial stabilization, particularly in hemodynamically unstable patients. Pins are placed in the iliac wings or anterior inferior iliac spine. (Option B)
  • Definitive Repair: Undertaken once the patient is stable ; Various techniques include anterior symphyseal plating, ORIF of the ilium, or sacroiliac screw placement depending on the fracture type. (Option C)

Urethral Injuries:

  • More common in males, with the membranous urethra being the most commonly affected site.
  • Rupture can be complete or incomplete, partial or full thickness.
  • Cardinal signs of urethral injury: Blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, distended bladder.
  • Treatment:
    • Drainage of the bladder via suprapubic cystostomy.
    • Micturating cysto-urethrogram after 6 weeks to assess for urethral stricture, followed by appropriate treatment.

Bladder Injuries:

  • Extraperitoneal injuries are treated nonoperatively.
  • Intraperitoneal injuries require surgical repair.

Sigmoid and Rectal Injuries:

  • Intraperitoneal injuries are debrided and primarily repaired if possible.
  • Extraperitoneal rectal injuries are managed with primary repair and diverting colostomy.

Vaginal Lacerations: First-degree injuries are treated with gauze packing; second- and third-degree injuries require surgical repair.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD after a road traffic accident complaining of being unable to dorsiflex and evert the ankle. A X- ray was ordered by the attending physician. In addition to the observed injury on the X-ray, which gait abnormality is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stepping gait

Explanation:

X-ray shows fracture-neck of fibula, Common peroneal nerve injury is common as it winds around the neck of fibula - which leads to Foot drop (inability to dorsiflex/evert the ankle). Stepping gait is commonly seen in patients with foot drop.

X-Ray showing Fibular neck fracture

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Anatomy:
  • The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa.
  • Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2.
  • Hooks around the neck of the fibula.
  • Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve

Muscles supplied:
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion)
  • Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor hallucis longus.

Cutaneous supply of foot:

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Causes
  • Most common: Neck of fibula fracture
  • Posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture lateral tibial condyle

Clinical features
  • Foot drop (inability to evert)
  • High stepping gait (Option A)

Treatment
  • Conservative (mainstay): Foot drop splint

  • Surgical (tendon transfer) - only done >12 months of no recovery:
    • Barr’s technique
    • Ober’s technique

Various gaits:

Scissoring gait

Cerebral palsy

Stepping gait

Foot drop

Ataxic gait

Cerebellar ataxia

Circumduction gait (Option C)

Stroke

Waddling gait (Option B)

Hip abductors palsy

Stamping gait (Option D)

Tabes dorsalis

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a proximal 1/3rd fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Interlocking nail:

  • Interlocking nails are frequently employed for tibia and femur shaft fractures in adults, providing stability via a frictional fit within the medullary canal and interlocking screws that anchor the bone to the nail. This method offers better control over length and torsion than unlocked nails.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: In fractures occurring in the proximal one-third of the femoral shaft, vigorous muscle contractions can lead to significant displacement of the fracture. Consequently, traditional immobilization methods such as hip spica, above knee slab, and above knee cast may not effectively maintain alignment.

questions.text: The diagnosis in a patient who is unable to do internal and external rotation of the hip is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Dislocation of the hip

Explanation:

The attitude of the lower limb in the dislocation of the hip is flexed, adducted and fully internally rotated which makes it impossible for further internal or external rotation of the hip.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Femur Head Fracture (Option A) may affect hip movement, it doesn't specifically cause a loss of both internal and external rotation as prominently as a dislocation

Acetabular Fractures (Option B) may not result in an absolute inability to perform internal and external rotation unless they are associated with significant displacement or damage to the surrounding structures.

Pelvic Fracture (Option D does not typically cause a complete loss of internal and external rotation of the hip, unless there is concurrent injury to the hip joint itself.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to lesser trochanter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Psoas major muscle

Explanation:

Hip flexors, including their origin, attachment, and function:

Hip Flexor Muscle

Origin

Attachment

Function

Iliopsoas (Psoas major + Iliacus)
  • Psoas major: Transverse processes of T12-L5 vertebrae
  • Iliacus: Iliac fossa of the pelvis
  • Both muscles combine and attach at the lesser trochanter of the femur
  • Primary hip flexor
  • Flexion of the hip joint
  • Assists in trunk flexion (psoas)

Rectus Femoris
  • Anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) and acetabulum
  • Tibial tuberosity via the patellar tendon
  • Flexion of the hip
  • Extends the knee

Sartorius
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Medial surface of the tibia (Pes anserinus)
  • Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the hip
  • Flexion of the knee

Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL)
  • Anterior part of the iliac crest
  • Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS)
  • Iliotibial band (ITB), which attaches to the lateral condyle of the tibia
  • Flexion and abduction of the hip
  • Medial rotation of the hip

Pectineus
  • Pectineal line of the pubis
  • Pectineal line of the femur
  • Flexion and adduction of the hip

Adductor Longus
  • Pubic bone near the pubic symphysis
  • Medial linea aspera of the femur
  • Flexion of the hip (when the hip is in extension)
  • Adduction of the hip

Psoas minor (Option B)

  • Inserted into the illiopectinal eminence
  • Innervated by the anterior rami of L1, 2
  • Flexes the thigh

Obturator internus (Option C)

  • Inserted into greater trochanter of the femur
  • Innervated by the nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

Piriformis (Option A)

  • Inserts superiorly into the tip of the greater trochanter.
  • Innervated by the branches of anterior rami (S1, S2)
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

questions.text: Football player gets blow to the outer knee during match. Which structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B:

  • The MCL is a ligament located on the inner side of the knee joint that helps stabilize the knee against excessive sideways or valgus stress. It connects the femur (thigh bone) to the tibia (shin bone) and plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the knee joint.
  • When the knee undergoes a forceful impact from the outer side, such as a blow to the outer knee during sports like football, it can result in a valgus stress on the knee. This valgus force can cause the MCL to stretch or tear, resulting in an MCL injury.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL): While the ACL is another important ligament in the knee, it is not directly associated with MCL injuries. The ACL is located inside the knee joint and is responsible for controlling rotational and anterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Option C. Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL): The PCL is also an internal ligament of the knee, but it is not commonly associated with MCL injuries. The PCL helps stabilize the knee against posterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur.

Option D. Lateral meniscus: The lateral meniscus is the counterpart of the medial meniscus and is located on the outer side of the knee joint. It is not directly associated with MCL injuries. However, it can be injured independently or in conjunction with other knee injuries.

questions.text: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee. A plain radiograph is shown below. What is the best treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tension band wiring with K-wires:

  • The X-ray reveals a two-part fracture of the patella, typically caused by direct impact, falling on a bent knee, or sudden twisting.
  • Such fractures are common among active individuals, especially in sports-related incidents.
  • Tension band wiring with K-wires, utilizing two K-wires and a tension band wire, stabilizes the fracture and promotes healing.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option B - Tension band wiring with cancellous screws treats displaced patellar fractures but poses risks like infection, hardware failure, and knee stiffness.

Option C - Cylinder cast immobilization, used for non-displaced patellar fractures or postoperative care, involves a long-leg cast or brace from hip to ankle, promoting knee joint immobilization for healing.

Option D - Patellectomy, the last resort for severe patellar fractures, involves surgical patella removal, with potential functional limitations, making it unsuitable for all cases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male has been suffering from a progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past six months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve with exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of arthritis primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints, more common in males and starting in late teens to early adulthood.
  • Key symptoms include morning stiffness and back pain, alleviated by exercise. Other signs may include fatigue, fever, and weight loss. It's often linked with inflammatory bowel disease, like ulcerative colitis.
  • The characteristic "bamboo spine" appearance results from vertebrae bridging.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pott’s spine: Pott's spine, also known as tuberculosis of the spine, presents with similar symptoms to ankylosing spondylitis, but it typically affects only one or two vertebrae and can lead to vertebral collapse and deformity. 

Option B - Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis can affect any joint in the body, but it often affects the fingers and toes. Patients may also develop nail changes or skin lesions. 

Option D - Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis affects smaller joints, such as the hands and feet, and can cause joint pain, swelling, and stiffness.

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to inter – trochanteric fracture, and opt for the correct ones  :


	More common in males than females
	One – year mortality rate is about 20 to 30%
	It is more commonly associated with non – union than fracture neck of femur
	One year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2 and 4 are correct: 

Statement 2: One-year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% - This statement is correct. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures can range from 20 to 30%, depending on various factors such as the patient's age, overall health, and the presence of comorbidities.

Statement 4: One-year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours - This statement is correct. Early surgical intervention within 48 hours of the fracture has been shown to reduce the risk of complications and improve outcomes, including the mortality rate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1 and 3 are correct:

  • Statement 1: More common in males than females - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures do not show a significant gender predilection and can occur in both males and females.
  • Statement 3: It is more commonly associated with non-union than fracture neck of femur - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures generally have a lower risk of non-union compared to fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B - 1, 2, 3 are correct:

  • Statement 2: One-year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% - This statement is incorrect. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures is typically lower than 20-30%.

Option D - 1, 2, 3, 4 are correct:

  • The correct option is C: 2 and 4 are correct. The statements regarding the one-year mortality rate and the ability to reduce mortality by operating within 48 hours are accurate, while the statements about the gender distribution and association with non-union are incorrect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following test is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Thomas test:

  • This test is used to assess the presence of hip flexion contracture and to measure hip extension.
  • If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option C - Telescopy:

  • Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing for abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement.

 

Option B - Lasegue test:

  • Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression.

 

Option D - McMurray test:

  • Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a noticeable deformity of the neck and upper back. On physical examination, the patient's scapula is observed to be elevated and medially rotated, giving it the appearance of an equilateral triangle. The patient also has limited neck mobility. The patient and their family report that the deformity has been present since birth and has not improved over time. What is the likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Klippel-Feil deformity:

  • This congenital condition involves a fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae, resulting in a short neck and limited neck mobility.
  • The characteristic "triangular" appearance of the neck due to scapular elevation and medial rotation is a hallmark of Klippel-Feil deformity.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Separated shoulder deformity: This refers to a type of shoulder injury where the acromioclavicular joint is sprained or dislocated due to trauma.

Option B - Torticollis: Torticollis, also known as wry neck, is a condition characterized by the abnormal positioning or tilting of the head, often due to muscle spasms or contractures.

Option D - Congenital scoliosi: Congenital scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine that is present at birth and is due to malformations of the vertebrae. It can cause asymmetry in the shoulders and hips but does not typically present with the specific elevated and medially rotated scapula described in the question

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery:

  • Medial Circumflex Femoral Artery (MCFA): The MCFA is a branch of the deep femoral artery and provides the primary blood supply to the femoral head. Disruption or occlusion of this artery can lead to compromised blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in avascular necrosis.
  • The diagnosis and management of avascular necrosis of the femoral head typically involve a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (such as X-rays, MRI, or bone scans), and treatment options ranging from conservative measures to surgical interventions, depending on the severity and stage of the condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lateral Circumflex Femoral Artery (LCFA): The LCFA is also a branch of the deep femoral artery, but it primarily supplies blood to the muscles around the hip joint and does not directly supply the femoral head.

Option C - Obturator Artery: The obturator artery primarily supplies blood to the muscles of the medial thigh and does not directly supply the femoral head.

Option D: None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?

choices.text: Superior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension
Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

  • Patellar clunk syndrome (PCS) is attributed to the formation of a fibrous nodule at the junction of the proximal (superior) patellar pole and the articular aspect of the quadriceps tendon. This nodule becomes entrapped in the intercondylar box of the femoral component during knee flexion. Upon knee extension to 30-45 degrees, the nodule suddenly dislodges, resulting in a painful audible clunk

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient came with a flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following test is useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thomas test

 

Explanation:

 

Thomas test:

  • The Thomas test is specifically designed to detect hip flexion contracture.

  • The patient lies supine, and one hip is maximally flexed to flatten the lumbar spine and stabilize the pelvis. If the opposite leg lifts off the table (instead of staying flat), it indicates a flexion contracture of the contralateral hip.

  • It is commonly used in elderly patients or individuals with hip arthritis or postural abnormalities.

Thomas test is the most appropriate and specific clinical test to diagnose hip flexion contracture.

Allen’s test (Option A):

  • Is used to assess arterial blood flow to the hand, especially the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries before arterial blood gas sampling or cannulation.

  • Not related to hip joint pathology.

Trendelenburg test (Option B):

  • Assesses the integrity of the hip abductor muscles, particularly the gluteus medius and minimus.

  • A positive test indicates weakness or instability in these muscles (e.g., due to superior gluteal nerve injury), not a flexion contracture.

Ober test (Option D):

  • Used to detect iliotibial band (IT band) tightness or contracture.

  • The patient lies on the unaffected side, and the examiner extends and abducts the affected leg, then allows it to drop. If it remains elevated, it suggests IT band tightness.

  • Not specific for hip flexion contracture.

questions.text: Given below is the X ray of a newborn. What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Congenital Scoliosis:

  • This type of scoliosis is present at birth and is caused by abnormal spinal development during fetal development.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Postural Scoliosis:

  • Also known as non-structural scoliosis, this type of scoliosis is reversible and typically caused by factors such as poor posture, muscle imbalances, or leg length discrepancy. It does not involve any structural abnormalities of the spine.

Option C - Infantile Scoliosis:

  • This type of scoliosis develops in children younger than three years old. The cause is often unknown, and it can spontaneously resolve or progress over time.

Option D - Degenerative Scoliosis:

  • Also known as adult-onset scoliosis, this type of scoliosis occurs later in life due to degenerative changes in the spine, such as disc degeneration, osteoporosis, or spinal arthritis.

questions.text: A child presents to the orthopedic OPD with a limp and limb shortening. His X-ray is given below, What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - DDH:

  • The X-ray shows a dislocated hip joint with hip dysplasia and apparent limb shortening.
  • Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH), also known as congenital hip dysplasia or hip dislocation, refers to abnormal development of the hip joint, leading to instability, subluxation, or dislocation of the femoral head from the acetabulum. It commonly presents with a limp and limb length discrepancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Perthes: Perthes disease (Legg-Calve-Perthes disease) is a condition characterized by avascular necrosis of the femoral head, leading to deformity and hip joint dysfunction.

Option B - SCFE (Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis): SCFE is a condition where the femoral head slips off the femoral neck, causing hip pain and limping.

Option D - Fracture Neck of Femur: A fracture of the neck of the femur typically presents with localized pain, inability to bear weight, and external rotation of the affected limb.

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had  a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis. Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hemiarthroplasty:

  • The X-ray shows a fracture of the neck of the femur (hip fracture). In older patients, especially those over 65 years, surgical management with hemiarthroplasty (partial hip replacement) is often the preferred treatment for displaced femoral neck fractures.
  • Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the fractured head of the femur with a prosthetic implant while leaving the acetabulum intact. This procedure helps to restore hip function, relieve pain, and allow early mobilization.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hip Spica: Hip spica is a type of cast or brace used to immobilize the hip and surrounding areas. However, it is not the treatment of choice for a femoral neck fracture, especially in older patients. Immobilization alone does not provide adequate stability and may result in complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores.

Option C - Total Hip Replacement: Total hip replacement is not typically performed for femoral neck fractures, especially in older patients.

Option D - Nailing: Nailing may be a treatment option for certain types of femoral fractures but is not the preferred treatment for femoral neck fractures.

questions.text: Blount Disease results from the  involvement of
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Proximal Tibia:

  • Blount Disease, also known as tibia vara, is a growth disorder that primarily affects the proximal tibia
  • Main symptoms include noticeable leg bowing, leg pain, walking difficulty, and an abnormal gait.
  • Diagnosis involves physical examination and imaging tests like X-rays.
  • Treatment depends on age, severity, and complications, with options ranging from bracing and physical therapy to surgery for severe cases.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Distal Tibia: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal tibia.

Option C - Proximal Femur: Blount Disease does not involve the proximal femur.

Option D - Distal Femur: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal femur.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posterior dislocation of the hip:

  • In posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head is displaced posteriorly from the acetabulum.
  • It is the most common type of hip dislocation resulting from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident.
  • Mode of injury: Axial force applied to a flexed, adducted,and internally rotated hip.
  • Example: Dashboard injury.
  • 50% of PDH are associated with posterior chip fracture of acetabulum.
    • Plain x-ray won't give any results.
    • A CT scan is the investigation of choice in dislocationwith fractures.
  • Differentiation of PDH and ADH on x-ray
    • In ADH - Head is larger
    • In PDH - Smaller head

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central dislocation of the hip:

  • This term is not commonly used to describe hip dislocations. Central dislocation usually refers to a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced centrally within the acetabulum. It is a rare condition and not typically seen in traumatic injuries.

Option B - Fracture shaft of femur:

  • This refers to a fracture along the shaft (middle portion) of the femur bone. It does not directly involve the hip joint.

Option D - Anterior dislocation of the hip:

  • This is a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced anteriorly (towards the front) from the acetabulum. It is less common than posterior dislocation but can occur in certain traumatic situations.

questions.text: Identify the shown image
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Patella Tendon Bearing Brace:

  • A patella tendon bearing brace, also known as a patellar tendon brace or patellar tendon strap, is a specialized brace designed to provide targeted support and compression to the patellar tendon. It is commonly used in conditions such as patellar tendonitis or jumper's knee, where there is pain or inflammation in the patellar tendon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ankle Knee Stabilizer: An ankle knee stabilizer is a type of brace or support that provides stability to both the ankle and knee joints. It is commonly used in cases of ligament injuries or instability in these joints.

Option C - Thomas Splint: The Thomas splint is a specific type of splint used for immobilization and stabilization of the femur or thigh bone. It is commonly used in cases of fractures or dislocations of the femur.

Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect
